title: 112_s922
content: The Urban Jobs Act of 2011 may be cited as the ``Urban Jobs Act of 2011''. The purpose of the Act is to address urban job issues. Congress finds that one-third of minority youth are unemployed, the labor force participation rate for persons without a high school diploma is significantly lower, African-American and Hispanic students have a lower graduation rate, high school dropouts from 2004 will cost the nation billions in lost wages, taxes, and productivity, and only 52 percent of students in the 50 largest cities graduate from high school. The high school graduation rate in the United States is below the national average of 70 percent and the urban district average of 60 percent. High school dropouts earn significantly less over a lifetime compared to graduates. A large percentage of prison inmates have not completed high school. Increasing the graduation rate by 1 percent could save $1.4 billion annually in crime-related costs. A 10-percent increase in the male graduation rate could reduce arrest rates. According to a recent study, a 10% increase in male high school graduation rates could significantly reduce arrest rates for various crimes. The purpose of the Act is to provide resources for national nonprofit organizations to prevent disproportionate youth incarceration, especially among minority youth, and prepare them for employment or education leading to economic self-sufficiency. Services include job training, education, and support. SEC. 3. URBAN JOBS PROGRAMS. Amends the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 to include a new section on Urban Jobs Programs. The purpose of this section is to provide competitive grants for establishing a feeder system for youth in urban communities, offering holistic preparation for employment or education leading to employment, and preventing disproportionate youth incarceration. The section aims to provide grants to establish a feeder system for urban youth, focusing on reducing disproportionate incarceration of eligible youth in urban communities. Definitions include terms like community-based affiliate, eligible youth, and national intermediary. A national intermediary is defined as a nonprofit organization with an affiliate network in urban communities, expertise in youth outreach, and 20+ years of operation in 25 states. Recidivism is the tendency to return to criminal behavior, while an unsubsidized job is one that pays wages without public funds. The Urban Jobs Program provides grants to national intermediaries for comprehensive services to urban youth for employment or education leading to employment. The program aims to create job opportunities without relying on public funds. To be eligible for a grant under the Urban Jobs Program, a national intermediary must submit an application with specified grant amount and proposed uses of funds. The application must also outline how the intermediary will meet goals for participants in the program. The Urban Jobs Program aims to increase long-term employment in unsubsidized jobs, reduce recidivism, improve education attainment, literacy, and numeracy skills, and help participants earn industry-recognized certificates or credentials. The Urban Jobs Program aims to increase long-term employment in unsubsidized jobs, reduce recidivism, improve education attainment, literacy, and numeracy skills, and help participants earn industry-recognized certificates or credentials. The program includes engaged community partners, staff expertise in youth development, and an understanding of youth characteristics to create caring relationships and goals for program participants. The Urban Jobs Program focuses on creating goals such as employment, education attainment, industry-recognized certificates, and community service. The Urban Jobs Program aims to develop 21st-century workplace skills, foster a sense of responsibility for the future, create plans to achieve goals, reduce risk-taking behaviors, and improve educational outcomes. The Urban Jobs Program aims to improve educational outcomes, employment opportunities, and reduce recidivism through activities leading to industry-recognized certificates or credentials. The Urban Jobs Program offers a comprehensive set of services including case management and educational services such as skill assessment, remediation, and preparation for high school equivalency. It also provides opportunities for industry-recognized certificates or credentials and higher education entry. The Urban Jobs Program offers a range of services including educational support for high school equivalency, industry certificates, and higher education entry. It also includes job readiness activities, support services like health and housing assistance, and transportation. Only 2 percent of funds can be used for these services each fiscal year. The Urban Jobs Program offers various services such as educational support, job readiness activities, and support services like health and housing assistance. Not more than 2 percent of funds can be used for expenses associated with carrying out the program each fiscal year. The Secretary of Labor is required to submit a report detailing the progress made in establishing Urban Jobs Programs through national intermediaries. The program is not subject to evaluations required under a specific section. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, established by the Secretary of Labor, consists of 11 members from the private sector with experience in hiring and employee relations. The program is not subject to evaluations required under section 172. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, established by the Secretary of Labor, consists of 11 members from the private sector with experience in oversight, hiring, employee training, and employee relations. Members are appointed for life and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Committee's duties include analyzing and preparing recommendations for the Secretary on the design and operation of the program. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, comprised of 11 private sector members, analyzes and prepares recommendations for the Secretary on program design, long-term priorities, and guidelines. Members do not receive compensation but may have travel expenses covered. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee members do not receive compensation for their services but are allowed travel expenses. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Committee without reimbursement. Government employees can be detailed to the Committee without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Committee. Congress recommends that a community-based affiliate establish a local jobs council advisory committee, with at least one-third of the members being employers in high-impact industries. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 is amended to include funding for Urban Jobs Programs, with increasing amounts allocated for fiscal years 2012 to 2016. Additionally, a recommendation is made for a local jobs council advisory committee to include at least one-third of members from high-impact industries. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 is amended to include funding for Urban Jobs Programs, with increasing amounts allocated for fiscal years 2012 to 2016. Additionally, amendments are made to section 173A by inserting a period at the end and adding new items after it. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 is amended to include funding for Urban Jobs Programs under Sec. 173B, with increasing amounts allocated for fiscal years 2012 to 2016.
